_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary



Facility:    MFA Bulk Plant - Hale

Location:    30749 J Hwy., Hale, Mo.

Contact:     Bill Hapes

Phone:     660-565-2216





1. The Facility Policy



    MFA Incorporated, and the employees of the MFA Bulk Plant in Hale are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Hale Fire Protection District, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information



    The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient.



    The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored at any one time would be 265,370 pounds. The facility has (1) 26,000 gallon storage tank that would be the largest tank onsite. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport truck holding approximately 50,000 pounds. The facility also has (28) 1,000 gallon nurse tanks and two 1,450 gallon nurse tanks for product distribution.  



3. The Accident Release Prevention Program.



    The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1999", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".



4. The Five-year Accident History



    There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program.



    The facility

has;

    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA

       Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency

       planning and community right-to-know information as

       required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



    c. employees will not respond to any releases other than to 

           activate an emergency shut-off valve while evacuating the 

           facility if it is safe for them to do so. Local responders 

           will be notified to control any release.



6. Planned changes to improve safety.



    Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.





    3/19/12
